qas.question: What do some non-theists view God as?

answers.text: a symbol of human values and aspirations

qas.question: Although a proclaimed atheist, who was it that said "the word 'God' is to me a sound conveying no clear or distinct affirmation"?
In NOMA, what should be used to answer questions about the physical world?
What should be used to answer ultimate questions on morality and meaning?
Name the nineteenth century English atheist?
What does Stephen Jay Gould call philosophy that deals in the supernatural?
What category does NOMA fall under?

plausible_answers.text: he disbelieved in the Christian god

qas.question: What did the 19th century non-theist Stephen Jay say specifically about God?

plausible_answers.text: should then be used to answer any empirical question about the natural world

qas.question: What should Christianity be used for in relation to nature?

plausible_answers.text: should be used to answer questions about ultimate meaning and moral value

qas.question: What should philosophy be used for in relation to morality?
Where does a lack of supernatural influence make human values a sole player in?
What does NOMA avoid about God?

context: Even non-theist views about gods vary. Some non-theists avoid <b12_0>the concept of God<b12_0/>, whilst accepting that it is significant to many; other non-theists understand God as <a0_0>a symbol of human values and aspirations<a0_0/>. The nineteenth-century English atheist <a1_0><a5_0>Charles Bradlaugh<a5_0/><a1_0/> declared that he refused to say "There is no God", because "the word 'God' is to me a sound conveying no clear or distinct affirmation"; he said more specifically that <b8_0>he disbelieved in the Christian god<b8_0/>. Stephen Jay Gould proposed an approach dividing the world of philosophy into what he called "<a2_0><a6_0>non-overlapping magisteria<a2_0/>" (NOMA)<a6_0/>. In this view, questions of the supernatural, such as those relating to the existence and nature of God, are non-empirical and are the proper domain of theology. The methods of <a3_0>science<a3_0/> <b9_0>should then be used to answer any empirical question about the natural world<b9_0/>, and <a4_0><a7_0>theology<a7_0/><a4_0/> <b10_0>should be used to answer questions about ultimate meaning and moral value<b10_0/>. In this view, the perceived lack of any empirical footprint from the magisterium of the supernatural onto natural events makes science the sole player in <b11_0>the natural world<b11_0/>.
